1.name: Hydrogen
1.definition: Hydrogen is the lightest and most abundant chemical element in the universe. It is highly reactive and forms compounds with most elements. In its diatomic form (H₂), hydrogen is a colorless, odorless gas used extensively in chemical processes and fuel technologies.

2.name: Helium
2.definition: Helium is a colorless, odorless, tasteless, non-toxic, inert monatomic gas that heads the noble gas group. It is the second lightest and second most abundant element in the observable universe, primarily used in cryogenics and airships.

3.name: Lithium
3.definition: Lithium is a soft, silvery-white alkali metal. It is the lightest metal and is highly reactive. Lithium is widely used in rechargeable batteries for mobile phones, laptops, and electric vehicles.

4.name: Beryllium
4.definition: Beryllium is a hard, grayish metal naturally found in mineral rocks, coal, soil, and volcanic dust. It is used in aerospace materials due to its stiffness, light weight, and dimensional stability over a wide temperature range.

5.name: Boron
5.definition: Boron is a metalloid essential for plant growth and is commonly found in compounds such as borax. It is used in detergents, cosmetics, and as a semiconductor in electronics.

6.name: Carbon
6.definition: Carbon is the basis of organic chemistry and forms countless compounds. It exists in several allotropes including graphite, diamond, and graphene. Vital for life and industrial applications like steelmaking.

7.name: Nitrogen
7.definition: Nitrogen is a diatomic gas (N₂) constituting 78% of Earth's atmosphere. Essential for fertilizers (ammonia) and explosives. Liquid nitrogen is used in cryogenics.

8.name: Oxygen
8.definition: Oxygen is a life-sustaining gas (O₂) critical for respiration and combustion. Ozone (O₃) protects Earth from UV radiation. Most abundant element in the Earth's crust.

9.name: Fluorine
9.definition: Fluorine is the most electronegative element, forming highly reactive compounds like Teflon and fluoride. Used in toothpaste to prevent tooth decay.

10.name: Neon
10.definition: Neon is a noble gas known for its bright red-orange glow in neon lights. Chemically inert and used in cryogenics and laser technology.

11.name: Sodium
11.definition: Sodium is a highly reactive metal. Its compounds, like table salt (NaCl) and baking soda, are essential for biological functions and industrial processes.

12.name: Magnesium
12.definition: Magnesium is a lightweight metal critical for chlorophyll in plants and energy production in cells. Used in alloys for aerospace and automotive parts.

13.name: Aluminum
13.definition: Aluminum is a lightweight, corrosion-resistant metal used in construction, packaging (foil), and transportation. The most abundant metal in Earth's crust.

14.name: Silicon
14.definition: Silicon is the primary component of semiconductors and solar cells. Found in sand (SiO₂) and used extensively in electronics and glassmaking.

15.name: Phosphorus
15.definition: Phosphorus is essential for DNA, RNA, and ATP. Used in fertilizers, detergents, and matches. Exists in white, red, and black allotropes.

16.name: Sulfur
16.definition: Sulfur is a yellow crystalline solid. Used in sulfuric acid (industry), gunpowder, and vulcanization of rubber. Smells like rotten eggs in compounds.

17.name: Chlorine
17.definition: Chlorine is a toxic greenish-yellow gas (Cl₂). Used to disinfect water, produce PVC plastics, and in bleach. Forms salts like sodium chloride.

18.name: Argon
18.definition: Argon is an inert gas used in welding, lighting, and preserving historical documents. Third most abundant gas in Earth's atmosphere.

19.name: Potassium
19.definition: Potassium is a reactive metal vital for nerve function and agriculture (fertilizers). Found in bananas and used in fireworks (purple flame).

20.name: Calcium
20.definition: Calcium is essential for bones, teeth, and muscle function. Used in cement, plaster, and dietary supplements. Reacts vigorously with water.

21.name: Scandium
21.definition: Scandium is a rare earth metal with high melting point and low density. Used in aerospace alloys, high-intensity lamps, and sports equipment like baseball bats and bicycle frames.

22.name: Titanium
22.definition: Titanium is a strong, lightweight, corrosion-resistant metal used in aerospace, medical implants, and high-performance alloys. Known for its excellent strength-to-weight ratio.

23.name: Vanadium
23.definition: Vanadium strengthens steel alloys and is used in redox flow batteries. Named after Vanadis, the Scandinavian goddess of beauty.

24.name: Chromium
24.definition: Chromium is known for its shiny finish in stainless steel and chrome plating. Also used in dyes (chrome yellow) and as a catalyst.

25.name: Manganese
25.definition: Manganese strengthens steel and aluminum alloys. Essential for photosynthesis in plants and used in dry-cell batteries.

26.name: Iron
26.definition: Iron is a fundamental metal in construction and manufacturing, essential for blood hemoglobin in the body.

27.name: Cobalt
27.definition: Cobalt is used in alloys for aircraft engine parts and in batteries. Known for its vibrant blue compounds used in paints.

28.name: Nickel
28.definition: Nickel is used in stainless steel, coinage, and rechargeable batteries. Resistant to corrosion and oxidation.

29.name: Copper
29.definition: Copper is a highly conductive metal used in electrical wiring, plumbing, and coin production.

30.name: Zinc
30.definition: Zinc is an essential mineral in nutrition, used in galvanization to prevent rusting and in alloys.

31.name: Gallium
31.definition: Gallium is used in electronics, such as LEDs and semiconductors. Melts at around human body temperature.

32.name: Germanium
32.definition: Germanium is used in fiber optic systems, infrared optics, and solar cell applications.

33.name: Arsenic
33.definition: Arsenic is used in pesticides and electronics. Known for its toxic properties.

34.name: Selenium
34.definition: Selenium is essential in small amounts and is used in the glass industry and in solar cells.

35.name: Bromine
35.definition: Bromine is used in flame retardants and drilling fluids. It is a volatile, reddish-brown liquid at room temperature.

36.name: Krypton
36.definition: Krypton is a colorless, inert gas used in lighting and photography.

37.name: Rubidium
37.definition: Rubidium is used in electronics and specialty glasses. It is highly reactive, igniting spontaneously in air.

38.name: Strontium
38.definition: Strontium is used in fireworks and flares for a bright red color. Also in producing glass for color television cathode ray tubes.

39.name: Yttrium
39.definition: Yttrium is used in LED lights, phosphors, and superconductors. It plays a role in medical technologies and cell biology.

40.name: Zirconium
40.definition: Zirconium is corrosion-resistant and is used in nuclear reactors, ceramics, and medical applications.

41.name: Niobium
41.definition: Niobium improves the strength of steel alloys and is used in superconducting materials for powerful magnets.

42.name: Molybdenum
42.definition: Molybdenum is used to withstand high temperatures without expanding or softening greatly. Critical for steel and chemical industries.

43.name: Technetium
43.definition: Technetium is a radioactive metal used in medical diagnostic procedures and industrial radiography.

44.name: Ruthenium
44.definition: Ruthenium is used in electronics and in alloys with platinum. It hardens platinum and palladium for electrical contacts.

45.name: Rhodium
45.definition: Rhodium is rare and valuable, used in catalytic converters and jewelry.

46.name: Palladium
46.definition: Palladium is used in electronics, dentistry, and catalytic converters. It is flexible and does not tarnish easily.

47.name: Silver
47.definition: Silver is highly conductive and reflective, used in jewelry, electronics, and coins.

48.name: Cadmium
48.definition: Cadmium is used in batteries and pigments. It is toxic and requires careful handling.

49.name: Indium
49.definition: Indium is used in touchscreens, LCDs, and solders. It is soft, ductile, and has a low melting point.

50.name: Tin
50.definition: Tin is used in coatings to prevent corrosion and in soldering. It is malleable and ductile.

51.name: Antimony
51.definition: Antimony is used in flame retardants, semiconductor devices, and lead-acid batteries.

52.name: Tellurium
52.definition: Tellurium is used in metallurgy and electronics. It is a brittle, mildly toxic metalloid.

53.name: Iodine
53.definition: Iodine is used in antiseptics, dyes, and photographic chemicals. It is essential for thyroid health.

54.name: Xenon
54.definition: Xenon is used in lamps, anesthesia, and laser technology. It is a heavy, colorless gas.

55.name: Cesium
55.definition: Cesium is used in atomic clocks and photoelectric cells. It is one of the most reactive elements.

56.name: Barium
56.definition: Barium is used in drilling fluids for oil wells and in paints. It produces a bright green flame.

57.name: Lanthanum
57.definition: Lanthanum is used in camera lenses, electronic vacuum tubes, and catalytic converters.

58.name: Cerium
58.definition: Cerium is used in catalytic converters, glass polishing, and flints for lighters.

59.name: Praseodymium
59.definition: Praseodymium is used in aircraft engines, studio lighting, and permanent magnets.

60.name: Neodymium
60.definition: Neodymium is used in strong magnets, lasers, and ultraviolet-blocking glass.

61.name: Promethium
61.definition: Promethium is used in luminous paint, atomic batteries, and research.

62.name: Samarium
62.definition: Samarium is used in electronics, lasers, and nuclear reactors.

63.name: Europium
63.definition: Europium is used in phosphors, lasers, and neutron capture applications.

64.name: Gadolinium
64.definition: Gadolinium is used in MRI contrast agents, phosphors, and high-temperature superconductors.

65.name: Terbium
65.definition: Terbium is used in solid-state devices, fuel cells, and low-energy light bulbs.

66.name: Dysprosium
66.definition: Dysprosium is used in magnets, data storage devices, and nuclear reactors.

67.name: Holmium
67.definition: Holmium is used in magnets, nuclear reactors, and laser devices.

68.name: Erbium
68.definition: Erbium is used in optical fibers, amplifiers, and as a nuclear reactor control material.

69.name: Thulium
69.definition: Thulium is used in lasers, X-ray machines, and electronic devices.

70.name: Ytterbium
70.definition: Ytterbium improves the strength of stainless steel and is used in lasers.

71.name: Lutetium
71.definition: Lutetium is used in cancer therapy and as a catalyst in petroleum refining.

72.name: Hafnium
72.definition: Hafnium is used in nuclear reactors, integrated circuits, and superalloys.

73.name: Tantalum
73.definition: Tantalum is highly resistant to corrosion and is used in high-performance capacitors and surgical implants.

74.name: Tungsten
74.definition: Tungsten is known for its high melting point and is used in light bulb filaments, hard materials, and military applications.

75.name: Rhenium
75.definition: Rhenium is used in jet engines and as a catalyst in petroleum refining.

76.name: Osmium
76.definition: Osmium is the densest naturally occurring element and is used in fountain pen nibs and electrical contacts.

77.name: Iridium
77.definition: Iridium is a corrosion-resistant metal used in spark plugs, crucibles, and electrical contacts.

78.name: Platinum
78.definition: Platinum is used in jewelry, catalytic converters, and electronics. It is dense and malleable.

79.name: Gold
79.definition: Gold is used in jewelry, electronics, and as a monetary standard. Known for its malleability and resistance to corrosion.

80.name: Mercury
80.definition: Mercury is the only metal that is liquid at room temperature. Used in thermometers, barometers, and dental amalgams.

81.name: Thallium
81.definition: Thallium is used in electronics and pharmaceuticals. It is toxic and should be handled with care.

82.name: Lead
82.definition: Lead is used in batteries, radiation shields, and soldering. It is dense and malleable but toxic.

83.name: Bismuth
83.definition: Bismuth is used in cosmetics, pharmaceuticals, and ammo. It has a low thermal conductivity.

84.name: Polonium
84.definition: Polonium is radioactive and used as a heat source in space satellites and in antistatic devices.

85.name: Astatine
85.definition: Astatine is a rare and radioactive element, used in some cancer treatments and research.

86.name: Radon
86.definition: Radon is a radioactive gas used in radiation therapy. It can accumulate in homes from natural uranium decay.

87.name: Francium
87.definition: Francium is a highly radioactive metal with minimal applications due to its rarity and instability.

88.name: Radium
88.definition: Radium is radioactive and was once used in luminescent paints. Now used in medicine and as a radiation source.

89.name: Actinium
89.definition: Actinium is used in radiation therapy and as a neutron source.

90.name: Thorium
90.definition: Thorium is used in nuclear reactors and was formerly used in gas mantles.

91.name: Protactinium
91.definition: Protactinium is used in scientific research. It is a rare and toxic element.

92.name: Uranium
92.definition: Uranium is used as fuel in nuclear reactors and weapons. It is a dense, radioactive metal.

93.name: Neptunium
93.definition: Neptunium is used in research and as a precursor in plutonium production.

94.name: Plutonium
94.definition: Plutonium is used as a fuel in nuclear reactors and weapons. It is highly radioactive.

95.name: Americium
95.definition: Americium is used in smoke detectors and as a neutron source in industrial applications.

96.name: Curium
96.definition: Curium is used in space exploration as a heat source and for research purposes.

97.name: Berkelium
97.definition: Berkelium is used in research, particularly in the synthesis of heavier elements.

98.name: Californium
98.definition: Californium is used in neutron radiography and as a neutron source for research.

99.name: Einsteinium
99.definition: Einsteinium is used in scientific research and the synthesis of new elements.

100.name: Fermium
100.definition: Fermium is used in scientific research. It is a synthetic element.

101.name: Mendelevium
101.definition: Mendelevium is used in scientific research. It is named after Dmitri Mendeleev, the creator of the periodic table.

102.name: Nobelium
102.definition: Nobelium is used in scientific research. Named after Alfred Nobel, it is a synthetic element.

103.name: Lawrencium
103.definition: Lawrencium is used in scientific research. It is a synthetic element.

104.name: Rutherfordium
104.definition: Rutherfordium is used in scientific research. It is a synthetic element.

105.name: Dubnium
105.definition: Dubnium is used in scientific research. It is a synthetic element.

106.name: Seaborgium
106.definition: Seaborgium is used in scientific research. It is a synthetic element.

107.name: Bohrium
107.definition: Bohrium is used in scientific research. It is a synthetic element.

108.name: Hassium
108.definition: Hassium is used in scientific research. It is a synthetic element.

109.name: Meitnerium
109.definition: Meitnerium is used in scientific research. It is a synthetic element.

110.name: Darmstadtium
110.definition: Darmstadtium is used in scientific research. It is a synthetic element.

111.name: Roentgenium
111.definition: Roentgenium is used in scientific research. It is a synthetic element.

112.name: Copernicium
112.definition: Copernicium is used in scientific research. It is a synthetic element.

113.name: Nihonium
113.definition: Nihonium is used in scientific research. It is a synthetic element.

114.name: Flerovium
114.definition: Flerovium is used in scientific research. It is a synthetic element.

115.name: Moscovium
115.definition: Moscovium is used in scientific research. It is a synthetic element.

116.name: Livermorium
116.definition: Livermorium is used in scientific research. It is a synthetic element.

117.name: Tennessine
117.definition: Tennessine is used in scientific research. It is a synthetic element.

118.name: Oganesson
118.definition: Oganesson is an artificially created element that is expected to have properties similar to other noble gases. It was first synthesized in 2002 and remains one of the heaviest elements.
